newsitem.title: USA: U.S. lawmaker urges U.K. curb on N.Ireland marches.
newsitem.headline: U.S. lawmaker urges U.K. curb on N.Ireland marches.

text.p: U.S. Representative Joseph Kennedy filed a resolution in the U.S. House of Representatives on Wednesday urging the British government to ban marches by a Protestant group through Catholic areas in Northern Ireland.
Violence flared in Belfast after the Orange Order held a march on Sunday along the Catholic Garvaghy Road.
Two more parades are planned for the weekend in Belfast and in Londonderry. Hundreds of British troops were on their way to Northern Ireland on Thursday to help police combat potential violence.

"The resolution sends a clear and simple message to the British government and to Prime Minister Tony Blair: Orange Order marches should be banned along disputed routes," Kennedy said in a statement, adding that such parades "only serve to inflame tensions and further undermine the fragile peace process."
The parades are being staged on July 12, which marks the anniversary of a Protestant battle victory over a Catholic King which Protestants see as a landmark in entrenching their presence in Ireland.
Kennedy said the parades should either be banned or re-routed to prevent "ancient enmities from boiling over once more into needless confrontation."
Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat, and other U.S. lawmakers also called on members of the Orange Order to voluntarily refrain from marching through Catholic neighbourhoods.
The centuries-old Order says it is being wrongly blamed for the violence and wants only to hold peaceful marches to celebrate its Protestant faith and British loyalty.
